title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.1 data

ggplot(data=exam_data)














Note




A blank canvas appears.
ggplot() initializes a ggplot object.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.2 Aesthetic Mappings

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))














Note




X-axis is included here.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.3 geom

geom_bar()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) + 
  geom_bar()










geom_dotplot()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.















Warning




Misleading y-scale.




ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)  














Note




scale_y_continuous() is used to turn off the y-axis.





geom_histogram()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.











Modifying geom object

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue") 









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")










geom_density()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()










geom_boxplot()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)














Note




Notch is used to help visually assess whether the medians of distributions differ.





geom_violin()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()










geom_point()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() 










Combining geom objects

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.4 stat

stat_summary()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)   










geom_point()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun="mean",           
             colour="red",          
             size=4)  










geom_smooth()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.5 Facets

facet_wrap()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)










facet_grid()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.6 Coordinates

Flipping axis

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()










Changing axis range

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.7 Themes

GrayClassicMinimal



ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()











ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()











ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("../data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
4.1 Single graph

p1p2p3



p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

p1











p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")

p2











p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

p3

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
4.2 Composite graphs: patchwork

Two-Column Layout using the Plus Sign +.
Parenthesis () to create a subplot group.
Two-Row Layout using the Division Sign /


Combining 2 graphs

p1 + p2










Combining 3 graphs

(p1 / p2) | p3










Creating composite fig with tag

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')










Creating fig with insert

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)










Creating composite fig with patchwork & ggtheme

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()
